How is TQM addressed at M&M. Give 5 examples to substantiate the answer

Total Quality Management (TQM) is an approach to quality management that aims to achieve continuous improvement in all aspects of an organization. M&M has been a pioneer in implementing TQM practices in the automobile industry in India. Here are some examples of how M&M has addressed TQM:

1. Quality Circles: M&M encourages the formation of quality circles, which are small groups of employees who meet regularly to identify and solve problems related to quality. Quality circles have been implemented across M&M's operations, including manufacturing, supply chain, and customer service.
2. Lean Manufacturing: M&M has implemented lean manufacturing practices across its production lines to eliminate waste, reduce lead times, and improve efficiency. M&M's lean manufacturing approach focuses on continuous improvement, standardization, and visual management.
3. Six Sigma: M&M has implemented Six Sigma methodology to improve quality and reduce defects in its products and processes. Six Sigma is a data-driven approach to quality management that uses statistical methods to identify and eliminate sources of variability.
4. Supplier Quality Management: M&M has a robust supplier quality management system in place to ensure that its suppliers meet the company's quality standards. The system includes regular audits, quality control checks, and collaboration with suppliers to improve quality.
5. Customer Satisfaction: M&M places a high emphasis on customer satisfaction, and its quality management practices are designed to meet or exceed customer expectations. M&M collects customer feedback through various channels and uses that feedback to drive continuous improvement in its products and services.

Overall, M&M's approach to TQM is comprehensive, and it covers all aspects of its operations. The company's commitment to quality is evident in its continuous improvement efforts and the high level of customer satisfaction.
How is Inventory management addressed at M&M. Give 5 examples to substantiate the answer on the basis of criticality of individual item

Inventory management is a critical aspect of any business, and M&M has implemented several practices to manage its inventory effectively. Here are five examples of how M&M addresses inventory management on the basis of the criticality of individual items:

1. ABC Analysis: M&M uses the ABC analysis method to categorize its inventory based on its criticality. Items are classified as A, B, or C based on their relative importance. A items are high-value items that require close monitoring, while C items are low-value items that require less attention.
2. Just-in-Time (JIT) Inventory Management: M&M uses JIT inventory management to ensure that it has the right amount of inventory on hand to meet production demands. JIT involves ordering inventory only when it is needed, rather than keeping a large amount of inventory in stock.
3. Safety Stock: M&M maintains safety stock of critical items to ensure that it has enough inventory on hand to meet unexpected demand or supply chain disruptions. Safety stock levels are determined based on the criticality of the item, lead times, and demand variability.
4. Consignment Inventory: M&M works with some of its suppliers to maintain consignment inventory, which is inventory that is owned by the supplier until it is used by M&M. This helps M&M reduce its inventory carrying costs and ensures that it has access to critical items when it needs them.
5. Automated Inventory Management System: M&M uses an automated inventory management system to track inventory levels and movement. The system provides real-time visibility into inventory levels and alerts inventory managers when inventory levels are low or when there are supply chain disruptions.

Overall, M&M's approach to inventory management is comprehensive and includes a variety of practices that address the criticality of individual items. By using techniques such as ABC analysis, JIT inventory management, safety stock, consignment inventory, and an automated inventory management system, M&M can ensure that it has the right amount of inventory on hand to meet production demands while minimizing inventory carrying costs.
